clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) in Disordered Gambling
clinical_study.official_title: The Role of Neuromodulation for Cognitive Processing and Behavioural Inhibition in Disordered Gambling

brief_summary.textblock:
Disordered gambling is associated to high impulsivity and excessive risk-taking behaviour. These behavioural characteristics related to addiction are linked to cognitive processes in specific brain areas located in the prefrontal cortex (PFC).
With the aim of studying the role of PFC in disordered gambling, the investigators employ transcranial current direct stimulation (tDCS), a noninvasive brain stimulation technique that applies a very weak electrical current to the superficial areas of the brain.
The clinical phase of the research consists on studying the effects of tDCS in combination with cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) in patients that attend the United Kingdom (UK) National Problem Gambling Clinic. The main objective of the project is to investigate whether this technique can help to decrease impulsivity and risk-taking behaviour, and therefore offer improved opportunities for the treatment of disordered gambling.

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigators aim to have a total of 96 participants diagnosed with disordered gambling with the Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI). There will be 24 participants per condition (2 treatment groups x 2 conditions per group).
Participants will be split into two different treatment groups depending on whether they receive cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) after their tDCS session or not:
Treatment 1. Participants will attend 5 weekly sessions where they receive tDCS stimulation for 20 minutes, while complete CANTAB cognitive tasks to measure Executive Functions (EF) and gambling behaviour.
Treatment 2. Participants will attend 5 weekly sessions where they receive tDCS stimulation for 20 minutes, while complete CANTAB cognitive tasks to measure Executive Functions (EF) and gambling behaviour, and following this, they will also attend to a weekly CBT session.
In each treatment group, participants will be allocated to either one of two different stimulation conditions: "Real stimulation" condition involves the application of tDCS or "Sham stimulation" condition that is used as a control (similar to a placebo).
Participants will complete cognitive questionnaires (Gambling Related Cognitions Scale, Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance and Sensation Seeking (UPPS) Impulsivity Scale and Active Open Minded Thinking Scale) in the first and last sessions (session 1 and session 5).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Investigation of the effects of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) alone, and in combination with cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT). These two interventions will be evaluated in parallel against two control groups "Sham tDCS without CBT" and "Sham tDCS with CBT".
study_design_info.masking_description: Participants will be allocated either to a tDCS Stimulation condition or to a tDCS Sham condition.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Cambridge Gambling Task (CGT)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline CGT scores at week 5

primary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Multitasking Test (MTT)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline MTT scores at week 5

primary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Information Sampling Task (IST)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from week 2 impulsivity scores at week 4

primary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the Stop Signal Task (SST)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from week 2 inhibition scores at week 4

primary_outcome.measure: Change in scores on the One Touch Stockings of Cambridge (OTS)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from week 2 executive functions scores at week 4

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline GRCS scores at week 5
secondary_outcome.description: It contains 23 items using a 1-7 point scale ranging from strongly disagree to strongly agree, related to 5 types of gambling-related biases measured by the following subscales: illusion of control (possible values: 1-28), predictive control (possible values: 1-28), interpretative bias (possible values: 1-42), gambling expectancies (possible values: 1-35) and inability to stop gambling (possible values: 1-28). The total raw GRCS score (possible values: 5-161) will be measured by adding the five raw subscale scores. Higher scores represent higher level of cognitive distortions.

secondary_outcome.measure: Urgency, Premeditation, Perseverance and Sensation Seeking (UPPS-P) Impulsivity Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline UPPS-P scores at week 5
secondary_outcome.description: It contains 59 items with a 1-4 point scale ranging from strongly agree to strongly disagree, to identify the different personality traits of impulsivity measured by the following 5 subscales: negative urgency (possible values: 1-48), positive urgency (possible values: 1-56), lack of premeditation (possible values: 1-44), lack of perseverance (possible values: 1- 40) and sensation seeking (possible values: 1-48). The total raw UPPS-P score (possible values: 5-236) will be measured by adding the five raw subscale scores. Higher scores represent higher level of impulsivity.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline AOT scores at week 5
secondary_outcome.description: It contains 7 items with a 1-7 point scale ranging from completely disagree to completely agree. Assesses beliefs about whether actively open-minded thinking is perceived as good. Each of the 7 items is scored from values ranged 1-7. Adding the items scores result in the total raw score (possible values: 7-49). Higher scores represent higher levels of open minded thinking style.

arm_group.description: 24 participants will attend to one weekly tDCS stimulation session with intensity 1.5 milliamps for 5 consecutive weeks. One tDCS session per week (Total: 5 sessions).
24 participants will attend to one weekly Sham tDCS session with intensity 0 milliamps for 5 consecutive weeks. One Sham tDCS session per week (Total: 5 sessions).

24 participants will attend to one weekly tDCS stimulation session with intensity 1.5 milliamps for 5 consecutive weeks. Following the tDCS session, participants will attend to a cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) session. One tDCS + CBT session per week (Total: 5 sessions).

24 participants will attend to one weekly Sham tDCS session with intensity 0 milliamps for 5 consecutive weeks. Following the Sham tDCS session, participants will attend to a CBT session. One Sham tDCS + CBT session per week (Total: 5 sessions).

intervention.description: Transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) is a form of noninvasive brain stimulation that applies a very low electrical current to the scalp. tDCS will be applied by electrodes (5 x 5 cm2), with intensity of 1.5 milliamps in real stimulation condition and 0 milliamps in sham condition, during 20 minutes, using a high density (HD) tDCS montage (1 anode x 4 return) electrodes over the Prefrontal Cortex (PFC).

Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) is the current treatment available for disordered gamblers at the UK National Problem Gambling Clinic. During the therapy sessions patients acquire learning strategies, cognitive and motivational elements, and develop personal skills to help them improve the understanding of their problems.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or females between 18-65 years old diagnosed with disordered gambling based on the Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI) who can speak and read English and don't have any of the exclusion criteria.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. History or evidence of chronic or residual neurological disease.
2. A pacemaker or deep brain stimulation.
3. Metal implants in head or neck area (e.g. postoperative clips after intracerebral aneurysm; arterial aneurysm in the vascular system, implantation of an artificial hearing aid).
4. Intracerebral ischemia/history of bleeding.
5. Prior evidence of epileptic seizures, history of epilepsy.
6. History of head injury with loss of consciousness.
7. Any serious medical conditions (disease of the internal organs).
8. Pregnancy or breast-feeding.

patient_data.ipd_description: The participant's data are de-identified (i.e. direct and indirect identifiers have been removed and replaced by a code. The researcher is able to link the code to the original identifiers and isolate the participant to whom the data relates). The Data Protection Act (1998), is the primary legislation on data storage. It states that personal data can be kept for as long as it is needed in an anonymised state for the study, after which time it must be destroyed.
